citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, a blue and gold macaw was observed to have a markedly enlarged cervicothoracic region. The
breast area appeared significantly distended and abnormal. There is no evidence that the attending veterinarian had been
notified or consulted regarding the animal’s condition. Failure to identify and report this condition to the attending
veterinarian prevents timely diagnosis and appropriate treatment, placing the macaw at risk for pain, distress, or
worsening illness.
The facility must ensure that all animals are observed daily and that any signs of illness, injury, or abnormality are
promptly communicated to the attending veterinarian. A licensed veterinarian must evaluate the macaw, determine the
cause of the enlargement, and provide appropriate care. Documentation of the veterinary assessment and any prescribed
treatment must be maintained and made available for review.
To be corrected by 12-1-2025 based on inspection findings of 11-18-2025.

During the inspection, it was observed that members of the public were allowed to have direct contact with and feed a
lemur without a facility attendant present. The interaction took place at the animal's primary enclosure. There was no
public barrier and no attendants present to monitor the encounter or ensure safe and appropriate handling practices.
Allowing public feeding and contact with regulated animals without continuous supervision by a knowledgeable and
trained attendant presents a significant risk to both the animal and the public. Unsuitable interactions can lead to stress or
injury to the lemur and increase the risk of bites, scratches, or other adverse incidents involving the public.
The facility is responsible for ensuring that all public interactions with animals are continuously supervised by a trained
attendant to safeguard animal welfare and public safety. Immediate corrective action is necessary to ensure that all future
public–animal interactions occur only under proper supervision.
To be corrected by 11-19-2025 based on the inspection dated 11-18-2025.

During inspection, an exposed electrical outlet was observed inside the primary enclosure housing two kangaroos. The
outlet lacked an appropriate cover or protective barrier. This created a potential electrical shock and fire hazard, as the
animals could directly contact or manipulate the outlet.
The condition was not identified or corrected by the licensee prior to inspection, despite being clearly visible within the
enclosure. Failure to maintain facilities in good repair and free of hazardous conditions places the animals at significant
risk of injury.
The licensee must ensure that all electrical installations within or near animal enclosures are properly maintained,
covered, and protected from animal access to prevent potential harm.
To be corrected by 12-1-2025 based on the inspection dated 11-18-2025.

Numerous cobwebs were observed on the ceiling above the enclosure for the silver fox. The cobwebs have collected dust
and debris over time. Premises (buildings and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the
animals from injury and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart.

The enclosure housing 27 Parakeets has a wooden roof panel that is separated from the front wall creating a large open
space in the ceiling of the enclosure. The open space is large enough to allow parakeets to potentially escape the
enclosure.
Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed of suitable materials so that they are structurally sound. The
primary enclosures must be kept in good repair.
To be corrected by 12-1-2025 based on the inspection of 11-18-2025.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
During the inspection, a paint container and various maintenance equipment were observed stored within the area
housing guinea fowl. These materials were accessible to the animals and presented potential risks, including exposure to
toxic substances, ingestion of foreign materials, and physical injury from tools or equipment. Housing areas must be
maintained in a manner that protects animals from hazards and ensures their safety and well-being.
The presence of improperly stored paint and maintenance items in the primary animal area demonstrates a failure to
provide safe and properly maintained facilities as required by the Animal Welfare Act. This condition could compromise
the health and safety of the guinea fowl.
All paint, chemicals, tools, and maintenance equipment must be promptly removed from animal areas and stored in a
secure, designated location inaccessible to the guinea fowl. The facility must ensure that animal housing areas remain
free of hazardous materials at all times to protect the health and well-being of the animals.
This is a continuation of the report for the routine inspection conducted 11-18-2025 and contains the remaining non-
compliances found during the inspection. The exit briefing for the items included on this report was conducted on 11-18-
2025.
This inspection was conducted with the facility representative on 11-18-2025 The exit interview was conducted with the
facility representative on 11-18-2025.
Additional Inspectors:
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICEREnd Section

narrative:
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
At the time of inspection, a blue and gold macaw was observed to have a markedly enlarged cervicothoracic region. The 
breast area appeared significantly distended and abnormal. There is no evidence that the attending veterinarian had been 
notified or consulted regarding the animal’s condition. Failure to identify and report this condition to the attending 
veterinarian prevents timely diagnosis and appropriate treatment, placing the macaw at risk for pain, distress, or 
worsening illness. 
The facility must ensure that all animals are observed daily and that any signs of illness, injury, or abnormality are 
promptly communicated to the attending veterinarian. A licensed veterinarian must evaluate the macaw, determine the 
cause of the enlargement, and provide appropriate care. Documentation of the veterinary assessment and any prescribed 
treatment must be maintained and made available for review. 
 
To be corrected by 12-1-2025 based on inspection findings of 11-18-2025. 
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
During the inspection, it was observed that members of the public were allowed to have direct contact with and feed a 
lemur without a facility attendant present. The interaction took place at the animal's primary enclosure. There was no 
public barrier and no attendants present to monitor the encounter or ensure safe and appropriate handling practices. 
Allowing public feeding and contact with regulated animals without continuous supervision by a knowledgeable and 
trained attendant presents a significant risk to both the animal and the public. Unsuitable interactions can lead to stress or 
injury to the lemur and increase the risk of bites, scratches, or other adverse incidents involving the public. 
The facility is responsible for ensuring that all public interactions with animals are continuously supervised by a trained 
attendant to safeguard animal welfare and public safety. Immediate corrective action is necessary to ensure that all future 
public–animal interactions occur only under proper supervision. 
To be corrected by 11-19-2025 based on the inspection dated 11-18-2025. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general.

During inspection, an exposed electrical outlet was observed inside the primary enclosure housing two kangaroos. The 
outlet lacked an appropriate cover or protective barrier. This created a potential electrical shock and fire hazard, as the 
animals could directly contact or manipulate the outlet. 
The condition was not identified or corrected by the licensee prior to inspection, despite being clearly visible within the 
enclosure. Failure to maintain facilities in good repair and free of hazardous conditions places the animals at significant 
risk of injury. 
The licensee must ensure that all electrical installations within or near animal enclosures are properly maintained, 
covered, and protected from animal access to prevent potential harm. 
To be corrected by 12-1-2025 based on the inspection dated 11-18-2025. 
3.131(c)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
Numerous cobwebs were observed on the ceiling above the enclosure for the silver fox. The cobwebs have collected dust 
and debris over time. Premises (buildings and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the 
animals from injury and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. 
3.153(a) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The enclosure housing 27 Parakeets has a wooden roof panel that is separated from the front wall creating a large open 
space in the ceiling of the enclosure. The open space is large enough to allow parakeets to potentially escape the 
enclosure. 
Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed of suitable materials so that they are structurally sound. The 
primary enclosures must be kept in good repair. 
 
To be corrected by 12-1-2025 based on the inspection of 11-18-2025. 
3.158(c) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
During the inspection, a paint container and various maintenance equipment were observed stored within the area 
housing guinea fowl. These materials were accessible to the animals and presented potential risks, including exposure to 
toxic substances, ingestion of foreign materials, and physical injury from tools or equipment. Housing areas must be 
maintained in a manner that protects animals from hazards and ensures their safety and well-being. 
The presence of improperly stored paint and maintenance items in the primary animal area demonstrates a failure to 
provide safe and properly maintained facilities as required by the Animal Welfare Act. This condition could compromise 
the health and safety of the guinea fowl. 
All paint, chemicals, tools, and maintenance equipment must be promptly removed from animal areas and stored in a 
secure, designated location inaccessible to the guinea fowl. The facility must ensure that animal housing areas remain 
free of hazardous materials at all times to protect the health and well-being of the animals.

This is a continuation of the report for the routine inspection conducted 11-18-2025 and contains the remaining non-
compliances found during the inspection. The exit briefing for the items included on this report was conducted on 11-18-
2025. 
 
This inspection was conducted with the facility representative on 11-18-2025 The exit interview was conducted with the 
facility representative on 11-18-2025. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICEREnd Section
